docs.lead_paragraph: JACK CLARK, in the second year of a three-year, $8.7 million contract with the Boston Red Sox, has filed for bankruptcy and listed $6.7 million in debts. "He had some expensive hobbies, and I think they got ahead of him," said FLETCHER A. ROBBE of Long Beach, Calif., the ballplayer's lawyer. The 36-year-old Clark filed a Chapter 7 bankruptcy petition on July 30 in Santa Ana, Calif. Details of the filing appeared in The Orange County Register yesterday. Clark, batting only .211 and sidelined with shoulder injuries, could not be reached for comment.

docs.lead_paragraph: MARTY BARRETT, a former Boston Red Sox second baseman, has sued the team and its physician and part-owner, ARTHUR PAPPAS, charging that they were negligent in handling his knee injury in 1989. Pappas and a team representative, JIM SAMIA, declined to comment on the suit.

docs.lead_paragraph: Jean R. Yawkey, the majority owner of the Red Sox, a fixture at Fenway Park for almost half a century and a major Boston philanthropist, died yesterday at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston, six days after suffering a severe stoke. She was 83 years old. Despite reports that she had been in failing health last year, Mrs. Yawkey had continued to attend Red Sox home games.

headline.main: Jean R. Yawkey, Red Sox Owner And Philanthropist, Is Dead at 83

docs.lead_paragraph: According to Yogi Berra, only in baseball can it be deja vu all over again. So it goes in Boston that, at this time of year, more than a fair share of the Red Sox pennant hopes rest on Roger Clemens's shoulders. Rarely does the right-hander buckle under the load. He did not last year when, in spite of shoulder problems, he was 7-1 from August to the end of the season. He hasn't faltered this year in this second half, either, willing the Red Sox forward with his increasing tenacity and increasingly unhittable fastball.

docs.lead_paragraph: Doctors still are seeking the cause of relief pitcher JEFF GRAY'S illness four days after he collapsed in the Boston Red Sox's clubhouse, a spokesman said yesterday. Dr. ARTHUR PAPPAS, the Red Sox's team doctor, said no diagnosis has been made and that results of further tests were needed because "we're still dealing with slurring of speech and weakness in the right arm and leg."

docs.lead_paragraph: Less than three months after he was disciplined for cursing an umpire from the mound during the final game of the American League playoffs, Roger Clemens has had another run-in with authority, this time with a policeman working in a West Houston bar. According to the police in Houston, the 28-year-old Boston Red Sox pitcher and two-time Cy Young Award winner was arrested early yesterday after he jumped on the policeman's back and choked him as the officer was trying to arrest Clemens's older brother, Gary Clemens, 39, during a disturbance at the bar.

headline.main: Did You Catch What TV Missed?

docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: The Boston Red Sox, who have slipped out of the American League Eastern Division race, have lost their regular center fielder, Ellis Burks, for the rest of the season. Burks separated his right shoulder in a collision with the Boston left fielder, Mike Greenwell, last week in Oakland, Calif. Burks was sidelined from June 14 until Aug.

docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: Jim Rice, Boston's veteran designated hitter, will undergo elbow surgery early next week and be out for four to six weeks. Dr. Arthur Pappas, the Red Sox orthopedist, said yesterday that Rice had a bone chip in the back of his right elbow. Rice has been in an extended slump and is hitting only .238.
